PLACEHOLDER Functions and Graphs

Learning Objectives

  • Define what constitutes a function
  • Identify domain and range of functions
  • Understand different types of functions
  • Interpret and create function graphs

What is a Function?

A function is a relation where each input has exactly one output. We write this as f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y, where:

  • xxx is the input (independent variable)
  • yyy is the output (dependent variable)
  • fff is the function name

Function Notation

If f(x)=2x+3f(x) = 2x + 3f(x)=2x+3, then:

  • f(1)=2(1)+3=5f(1) = 2(1) + 3 = 5f(1)=2(1)+3=5
  • f(−2)=2(−2)+3=−1f(-2) = 2(-2) + 3 = -1f(−2)=2(−2)+3=−1
  • f(a)=2a+3f(a) = 2a + 3f(a)=2a+3

Domain and Range

Domain: The set of all possible input values (x-values)
Range: The set of all possible output values (y-values)

Example

For f(x)=x−2f(x) = \sqrt{x - 2}f(x)=x−2​:

  • Domain: x≥2x \geq 2x≥2 (since we can't take the square root of negative numbers)
  • Range: y≥0y \geq 0y≥0 (square root is always non-negative)

Types of Functions

Linear Functions

f(x)=mx+bf(x) = mx + b f(x)=mx+b

  • Slope: mmm
  • y-intercept: bbb
  • Graph: Straight line

Quadratic Functions

f(x)=ax2+bx+cf(x) = ax^2 + bx + c f(x)=ax2+bx+c

  • Vertex form: f(x)=a(x−h)2+kf(x) = a(x - h)^2 + kf(x)=a(x−h)2+k
  • Vertex: (h,k)(h, k)(h,k)
  • Graph: Parabola

Other Important Functions

  • Absolute Value: f(x)=∣x∣f(x) = |x|f(x)=∣x∣
  • Square Root: f(x)=xf(x) = \sqrt{x}f(x)=x​
  • Reciprocal: f(x)=1xf(x) = \frac{1}{x}f(x)=x1​

Transformations

Starting with a parent function f(x)f(x)f(x):

Transformation New Function Effect
Vertical shift up f(x)+kf(x) + kf(x)+k Move up kkk units
Vertical shift down f(x)−kf(x) - kf(x)−k Move down kkk units
Horizontal shift left f(x+h)f(x + h)f(x+h) Move left hhh units
Horizontal shift right f(x−h)f(x - h)f(x−h) Move right hhh units
Vertical stretch af(x)af(x)af(x) Stretch by factor aaa
Horizontal stretch f(xb)f(\frac{x}{b})f(bx​) Stretch by factor bbb

Key Concepts to Remember

  1. Vertical Line Test: A graph represents a function if every vertical line intersects it at most once
  2. Function Composition: (f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))(f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x))(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))
  3. Inverse Functions: If fff and ggg are inverses, then f(g(x))=xf(g(x)) = xf(g(x))=x and g(f(x))=xg(f(x)) = xg(f(x))=x

Practice Problems

Try working through these during class:

  1. Find the domain of f(x)=1x2−4f(x) = \frac{1}{x^2 - 4}f(x)=x2−41​
  2. Graph g(x)=∣x−2∣+1g(x) = |x - 2| + 1g(x)=∣x−2∣+1
  3. If f(x)=x2f(x) = x^2f(x)=x2 and g(x)=x+3g(x) = x + 3g(x)=x+3, find (f∘g)(x)(f \circ g)(x)(f∘g)(x)
